Comment: An interesting reply to the Bishop's Opening. Elzie apparently intends to fianchetto the QB and pressure Colvin's KP.

Almost a delayed King's Gambit. Clearly it catches Elzie off guard, because he plays an incredibly poor move in response.

Almost a delayed King's Gambit. Clearly it catches Elzie off guard, because he plays an incredibly poor move in response.
Chess is 2/3 psychology. If you can spring a variant on your opponent that he's unprepared for, you can often induce a mistake... like this blunder, for instance.
Colvin exchanges the Pawns before striking.
Lulled into a false sense of security, Elzie completes the exchange.
Ouch. Now it's a matter of how Elzie wants to lose.
The answer is quickly. 6...P-N3 7 QxKP ch folloed by 8 QxR would be how to lose slowly.
The King-hunt is on in earnest.
